conclusion: To determine the radius R of the circular path of the particle in the magnetic field, we need to follow these steps.
The particle starts from rest at hole a and accelerates through the potential difference U between plates M and N.
The kinetic energy gained by the particle is equal to the work done by the electric field: (1/2)mv^2 = qU.
Solving for the speed v: v = sqrt(2qU/m).
When the particle enters region I, it experiences a magnetic force due to the magnetic field B directed along the positive x-axis.
The magnetic force provides the centripetal force required for the circular motion: F_B = qvB.
This force acts perpendicular to the velocity and causes the particle to move in a circular path.
The centripetal force required for circular motion is: F_c = mv^2/R.
Equating the magnetic force to the centripetal force: qvB = mv^2/R.
Solving for the radius R: R = mv/(qB).
Substitute the expression for v from Step 1: R = (m sqrt(2qU/m))/(qB) = sqrt(2mqU)/(qB) = sqrt(2mU)/(B sqrt(q)).
The radius R of the circular path of the particle in the magnetic field is: R = sqrt(2mU)/(B sqrt(q)).
